natural problem:
Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix}.\]
natural solution: We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos b \\ \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \cos (a - b) \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & \cos b \\ \cos a  & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \cos a \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & 1 \\ \cos a  & \cos b \end{vmatrix} \\

&= (1 - \cos^2 b) - \cos (a - b)(\cos (a - b) - \cos a \cos b) + \cos a (\cos (a - b) \cos b - \cos a) \\ &= 1 - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 a \\

&= 1 - \cos^2 a - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + 2 \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b). \end{align}We can write \begin{align} 2 \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 (a - b) &= \cos (a - b) (2 \cos a \cos b - \cos (a - b)) \\

&= \cos (a - b) (\cos a \cos b - \sin a \sin b) \\ &= \cos (a - b) \cos (a + b) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} (\cos 2a + \cos 2b) \\ &= \cos^2 a - \frac{1}{2} + \cos^2 b - \frac{1}{2} \\ &= \cos^2 a + \cos^2 b - 1.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: real
shows  "det(matrix([[1, cos(a - b), cos a], [cos(a - b), 1, cos b], [cos a, cos b, 1]])) = 0"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos b \\ \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \cos (a - b) \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & \cos b \\ \cos a  & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \cos a \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & 1 \\ \cos a  & \cos b \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= (1 - \cos^2 b) - \cos (a - b)(\cos (a - b) - \cos a \cos b) + \cos a (\cos (a - b) \cos b - \cos a) \\ &= 1 - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 a \\
 &= 1 - \cos^2 a - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + 2 \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b). \end{align}We can write \begin{align} 2 \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 (a - b) &= \cos (a - b) (2 \cos a \cos b - \cos (a - b)) \\
 &= \cos (a - b) (\cos a \cos b - \sin a \sin b) \\ &= \cos (a - b) \cos (a + b) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} (\cos 2a + \cos 2b) \\ &= \cos^2 a - \frac{1}{2} + \cos^2 b - \frac{1}{2} \\ &= \cos^2 a + \cos^2 b - 1.
 \end{align}Therefore, the determinant is equal to $\boxed{0}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: real
shows  "det(matrix([[1, cos(a - b), cos a], [cos(a - b), 1, cos b], [cos a, cos b, 1]])) = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem:
Calculate the determinant of the matrix 

[[1, cos(a - b), cos a], 
 [cos(a - b), 1, cos b], 
 [cos a, cos b, 1]]

and prove that it equals zero.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: real
shows  "det (vector [1, cos (a - b), cos a], vector [cos (a - b), 1, cos b], vector [cos a, cos b, 1]) = 0"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos b \\ \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \cos (a - b) \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & \cos b \\ \cos a  & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \cos a \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & 1 \\ \cos a  & \cos b \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= (1 - \cos^2 b) - \cos (a - b)(\cos (a - b) - \cos a \cos b) + \cos a (\cos (a - b) \cos b - \cos a) \\ &= 1 - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 a \\
 &= 1 - \cos^2 a - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + 2 \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b). \end{align}We can write \begin{align} 2 \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 (a - b) &= \cos (a - b) (2 \cos a \cos b - \cos (a - b)) \\
 &= \cos (a - b) (\cos a \cos b - \sin a \sin b) \\ &= \cos (a - b) \cos (a + b) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} (\cos 2a + \cos 2b) \\ &= \cos^2 a - \frac{1}{2} + \cos^2 b - \frac{1}{2} \\ &= \cos^2 a + \cos^2 b - 1.
 \end{align}Therefore, the determinant is equal to $\boxed{0}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: real
shows  "det (vector [1, cos (a - b), cos a], vector [cos (a - b), 1, cos b], vector [cos a, cos b, 1]) = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem:
Determine whether the determinant of the matrix 
$$
\begin{pmatrix}
1 & \cos(a - b) & \cos a \\
\cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\
\cos a & \cos b & 1 \\
\end{pmatrix}
$$
is equal to zero.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "det (\<chi> i j. if (i, j) = (1, 1) then 1 else if (i, j) = (2, 2) then 1 else if (i, j) = (3, 3) then 1 else if (i, j) = (1, 2) then cos (a - b) else if (i, j) = (2, 1) then cos (a - b) else if (i, j) = (1, 3) then cos a else if (i, j) = (3, 1) then cos a else if (i, j) = (2, 3) then cos b else if (i, j) = (3, 2) then cos b else 0) = 0"
shows  "det (\<chi> i j. if (i, j) = (1, 1) then 1 else if (i, j) = (2, 2) then 1 else if (i, j) = (3, 3) then 1 else if (i, j) = (1, 2) then cos (a - b) else if (i, j) = (2, 1) then cos (a - b) else if (i, j) = (1, 3) then cos a else if (i, j) = (3, 1) then cos a else if (i, j) = (2, 3) then cos b else if (i, j) = (3, 2) then cos b else 0) = 0"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos b \\ \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \cos (a - b) \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & \cos b \\ \cos a  & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \cos a \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & 1 \\ \cos a  & \cos b \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= (1 - \cos^2 b) - \cos (a - b)(\cos (a - b) - \cos a \cos b) + \cos a (\cos (a - b) \cos b - \cos a) \\ &= 1 - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 a \\
 &= 1 - \cos^2 a - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + 2 \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b). \end{align}We can write \begin{align} 2 \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 (a - b) &= \cos (a - b) (2 \cos a \cos b - \cos (a - b)) \\
 &= \cos (a - b) (\cos a \cos b - \sin a \sin b) \\ &= \cos (a - b) \cos (a + b) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} (\cos 2a + \cos 2b) \\ &= \cos^2 a - \frac{1}{2} + \cos^2 b - \frac{1}{2} \\ &= \cos^2 a + \cos^2 b - 1.
 \end{align}Therefore, the determinant is equal to $\boxed{0}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "det (\<chi> i j. if (i, j) = (1, 1) then 1 else if (i, j) = (2, 2) then 1 else if (i, j) = (3, 3) then 1 else if (i, j) = (1, 2) then cos (a - b) else if (i, j) = (2, 1) then cos (a - b) else if (i, j) = (1, 3) then cos a else if (i, j) = (3, 1) then cos a else if (i, j) = (2, 3) then cos b else if (i, j) = (3, 2) then cos b else 0) = 0"
shows  "det (\<chi> i j. if (i, j) = (1, 1) then 1 else if (i, j) = (2, 2) then 1 else if (i, j) = (3, 3) then 1 else if (i, j) = (1, 2) then cos (a - b) else if (i, j) = (2, 1) then cos (a - b) else if (i, j) = (1, 3) then cos a else if (i, j) = (3, 1) then cos a else if (i, j) = (2, 3) then cos b else if (i, j) = (3, 2) then cos b else 0) = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem:
Find the determinant of a 3x3 matrix whose entries are defined as follows:

- The diagonal entries (1,1), (2,2), and (3,3) are 1.
- The entries (1,2) and (2,1) are cos(a - b).
- The entries (1,3) and (3,1) are cos(a).
- The entries (2,3) and (3,2) are cos(b).
- All other entries are 0.

The determinant of this matrix is 0.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. cos (x - y) = cos x * cos y + sin x * sin y"
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> j. if i = j then 1 else if j = 1 then cos (a - b) else if j = 2 then cos b else cos a))) = 0"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos b \\ \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \cos (a - b) \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & \cos b \\ \cos a  & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \cos a \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & 1 \\ \cos a  & \cos b \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= (1 - \cos^2 b) - \cos (a - b)(\cos (a - b) - \cos a \cos b) + \cos a (\cos (a - b) \cos b - \cos a) \\ &= 1 - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 a \\
 &= 1 - \cos^2 a - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + 2 \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b). \end{align}We can write \begin{align} 2 \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 (a - b) &= \cos (a - b) (2 \cos a \cos b - \cos (a - b)) \\
 &= \cos (a - b) (\cos a \cos b - \sin a \sin b) \\ &= \cos (a - b) \cos (a + b) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} (\cos 2a + \cos 2b) \\ &= \cos^2 a - \frac{1}{2} + \cos^2 b - \frac{1}{2} \\ &= \cos^2 a + \cos^2 b - 1.
 \end{align}Therefore, the determinant is equal to $\boxed{0}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. cos (x - y) = cos x * cos y + sin x * sin y"
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> j. if i = j then 1 else if j = 1 then cos (a - b) else if j = 2 then cos b else cos a))) = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Calculate the determinant of a 3x3 matrix where the diagonal elements are 1 and the off-diagonal elements are determined by the cosine of the difference between two real numbers a and b, cosine of b and cosine of a. The determinant of the matrix is 0.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: real
shows  "det (vector [1, cos (a - b), cos a],
             vector [cos (a - b), 1, cos b],
             vector [cos a, cos b, 1]) = 0"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos b \\ \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \cos (a - b) \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & \cos b \\ \cos a  & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \cos a \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & 1 \\ \cos a  & \cos b \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= (1 - \cos^2 b) - \cos (a - b)(\cos (a - b) - \cos a \cos b) + \cos a (\cos (a - b) \cos b - \cos a) \\ &= 1 - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 a \\
 &= 1 - \cos^2 a - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + 2 \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b). \end{align}We can write \begin{align} 2 \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 (a - b) &= \cos (a - b) (2 \cos a \cos b - \cos (a - b)) \\
 &= \cos (a - b) (\cos a \cos b - \sin a \sin b) \\ &= \cos (a - b) \cos (a + b) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} (\cos 2a + \cos 2b) \\ &= \cos^2 a - \frac{1}{2} + \cos^2 b - \frac{1}{2} \\ &= \cos^2 a + \cos^2 b - 1.
 \end{align}Therefore, the determinant is equal to $\boxed{0}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: real
shows  "det (vector [1, cos (a - b), cos a],
             vector [cos (a - b), 1, cos b],
             vector [cos a, cos b, 1]) = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem:
Determine whether the determinant of the following 3x3 matrix is equal to zero:
The first row is [1, cos(a - b), cos(a)], 
The second row is [cos(a - b), 1, cos(b)], 
The third row is [cos(a), cos(b), 1].

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: real
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> j. if (i = 0 ∧ j = 0) ∨ (i = 1 ∧ j = 1) ∨ (i = 2 ∧ j = 2) then 1 else if (i = 0 ∧ j = 1) ∨ (i = 1 ∧ j = 0) ∨ (i = 0 ∧ j = 2) ∨ (i = 2 ∧ j = 0) then cos a else if (i = 1 ∧ j = 2) ∨ (i = 2 ∧ j = 1) then cos b else cos (a - b)))) = 0"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos b \\ \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \cos (a - b) \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & \cos b \\ \cos a  & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \cos a \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & 1 \\ \cos a  & \cos b \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= (1 - \cos^2 b) - \cos (a - b)(\cos (a - b) - \cos a \cos b) + \cos a (\cos (a - b) \cos b - \cos a) \\ &= 1 - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 a \\
 &= 1 - \cos^2 a - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + 2 \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b). \end{align}We can write \begin{align} 2 \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 (a - b) &= \cos (a - b) (2 \cos a \cos b - \cos (a - b)) \\
 &= \cos (a - b) (\cos a \cos b - \sin a \sin b) \\ &= \cos (a - b) \cos (a + b) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} (\cos 2a + \cos 2b) \\ &= \cos^2 a - \frac{1}{2} + \cos^2 b - \frac{1}{2} \\ &= \cos^2 a + \cos^2 b - 1.
 \end{align}Therefore, the determinant is equal to $\boxed{0}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: real
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> j. if (i = 0 ∧ j = 0) ∨ (i = 1 ∧ j = 1) ∨ (i = 2 ∧ j = 2) then 1 else if (i = 0 ∧ j = 1) ∨ (i = 1 ∧ j = 0) ∨ (i = 0 ∧ j = 2) ∨ (i = 2 ∧ j = 0) then cos a else if (i = 1 ∧ j = 2) ∨ (i = 2 ∧ j = 1) then cos b else cos (a - b)))) = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Calculate the determinant of a 3x3 matrix where the diagonal elements are 1, the elements at positions (1,2), (2,1), (1,3), and (3,1) are equal to the cosine of 'a', the elements at positions (2,3) and (3,2) are equal to the cosine of 'b', and all remaining elements are equal to the cosine of 'a - b'. The determinant of this matrix is equal to 0.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: real
shows  "det (Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = j then 1 else (if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 \<or> i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then cos (a - b) else (if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 \<or> i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then cos a else cos b)))) = 0"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos b \\ \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \cos (a - b) \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & \cos b \\ \cos a  & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \cos a \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & 1 \\ \cos a  & \cos b \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= (1 - \cos^2 b) - \cos (a - b)(\cos (a - b) - \cos a \cos b) + \cos a (\cos (a - b) \cos b - \cos a) \\ &= 1 - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 a \\
 &= 1 - \cos^2 a - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + 2 \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b). \end{align}We can write \begin{align} 2 \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 (a - b) &= \cos (a - b) (2 \cos a \cos b - \cos (a - b)) \\
 &= \cos (a - b) (\cos a \cos b - \sin a \sin b) \\ &= \cos (a - b) \cos (a + b) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} (\cos 2a + \cos 2b) \\ &= \cos^2 a - \frac{1}{2} + \cos^2 b - \frac{1}{2} \\ &= \cos^2 a + \cos^2 b - 1.
 \end{align}Therefore, the determinant is equal to $\boxed{0}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: real
shows  "det (Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = j then 1 else (if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 \<or> i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then cos (a - b) else (if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 \<or> i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then cos a else cos b)))) = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: "Calculate the determinant of a 3x3 matrix where the diagonal elements are 1, the elements at positions (1,2) and (2,1) are cos(a-b), the elements at positions (1,3) and (3,1) are cos(a), and the remaining elements are cos(b). Show that this determinant equals 0."

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: real
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> j. if (i = j) then 1 else (if i = 1 then cos(a - b) else (if i = 2 then cos(a - b) else (if i = 3 then cos a else cos b)))))) = 0"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos b \\ \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \cos (a - b) \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & \cos b \\ \cos a  & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \cos a \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & 1 \\ \cos a  & \cos b \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= (1 - \cos^2 b) - \cos (a - b)(\cos (a - b) - \cos a \cos b) + \cos a (\cos (a - b) \cos b - \cos a) \\ &= 1 - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 a \\
 &= 1 - \cos^2 a - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + 2 \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b). \end{align}We can write \begin{align} 2 \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 (a - b) &= \cos (a - b) (2 \cos a \cos b - \cos (a - b)) \\
 &= \cos (a - b) (\cos a \cos b - \sin a \sin b) \\ &= \cos (a - b) \cos (a + b) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} (\cos 2a + \cos 2b) \\ &= \cos^2 a - \frac{1}{2} + \cos^2 b - \frac{1}{2} \\ &= \cos^2 a + \cos^2 b - 1.
 \end{align}Therefore, the determinant is equal to $\boxed{0}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: real
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> j. if (i = j) then 1 else (if i = 1 then cos(a - b) else (if i = 2 then cos(a - b) else (if i = 3 then cos a else cos b)))))) = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Calculate the determinant of a 3x3 matrix where the diagonal elements are 1 and the off-diagonal elements are defined as follows: if the row index is 1, use cos(a - b), if the row index is 2, use cos(a - b), if the row index is 3, use cos(a). For all other cases, use cos(b). The result will be zero.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: real
shows  "det(matrix([[1, cos(a-b), cos a], [cos(a-b), 1, cos b], [cos a, cos b, 1]]) = 0"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos b \\ \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \cos (a - b) \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & \cos b \\ \cos a  & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \cos a \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & 1 \\ \cos a  & \cos b \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= (1 - \cos^2 b) - \cos (a - b)(\cos (a - b) - \cos a \cos b) + \cos a (\cos (a - b) \cos b - \cos a) \\ &= 1 - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 a \\
 &= 1 - \cos^2 a - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + 2 \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b). \end{align}We can write \begin{align} 2 \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 (a - b) &= \cos (a - b) (2 \cos a \cos b - \cos (a - b)) \\
 &= \cos (a - b) (\cos a \cos b - \sin a \sin b) \\ &= \cos (a - b) \cos (a + b) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} (\cos 2a + \cos 2b) \\ &= \cos^2 a - \frac{1}{2} + \cos^2 b - \frac{1}{2} \\ &= \cos^2 a + \cos^2 b - 1.
 \end{align}Therefore, the determinant is equal to $\boxed{0}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: real
shows  "det(matrix([[1, cos(a-b), cos a], [cos(a-b), 1, cos b], [cos a, cos b, 1]]) = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem:
Determine whether the determinant of the following matrix equals zero:

[[1, cos(a-b), cos a],
 [cos(a-b), 1, cos b],
 [cos a, cos b, 1]]

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: real
shows  "det (Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i, j). if (i = j) then 1 else (if (i = 0 \<and> j = 1) \<or> (i = 1 \<and> j = 0) then cos(a - b) else (if (i = 0 \<and> j = 2) \<or> (i = 2 \<and> j = 0) then cos a else cos b)))) = 0"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos (a - b) & \cos a \\ \cos(a - b) & 1 & \cos b \\ \cos a & \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \cos b \\ \cos b & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \cos (a - b) \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & \cos b \\ \cos a  & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \cos a \begin{vmatrix} \cos (a - b) & 1 \\ \cos a  & \cos b \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= (1 - \cos^2 b) - \cos (a - b)(\cos (a - b) - \cos a \cos b) + \cos a (\cos (a - b) \cos b - \cos a) \\ &= 1 - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b) + \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 a \\
 &= 1 - \cos^2 a - \cos^2 b - \cos^2 (a - b) + 2 \cos a \cos b \cos(a - b). \end{align}We can write \begin{align} 2 \cos a \cos b \cos (a - b) - \cos^2 (a - b) &= \cos (a - b) (2 \cos a \cos b - \cos (a - b)) \\
 &= \cos (a - b) (\cos a \cos b - \sin a \sin b) \\ &= \cos (a - b) \cos (a + b) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} (\cos 2a + \cos 2b) \\ &= \cos^2 a - \frac{1}{2} + \cos^2 b - \frac{1}{2} \\ &= \cos^2 a + \cos^2 b - 1.
 \end{align}Therefore, the determinant is equal to $\boxed{0}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: real
shows  "det (Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i, j). if (i = j) then 1 else (if (i = 0 \<and> j = 1) \<or> (i = 1 \<and> j = 0) then cos(a - b) else (if (i = 0 \<and> j = 2) \<or> (i = 2 \<and> j = 0) then cos a else cos b)))) = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Calculate the determinant of a 3x3 matrix whose diagonal entries are all 1, the elements at positions (1,2) and (2,1) are cos(a-b), the elements at positions (1,3) and (3,1) are cos(a), and the remaining entries are cos(b). The determinant of this matrix is equal to 0.
